document.masterDocTitle: Sepedon (Diptera: Sciomyzidae) species from China, with notes on taxonomy and distribution

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sepedon (Diptera: Sciomyzidae) species from China, with notes on taxonomy and distribution

subSubSection.paragraph:
Sepedon aenescens Wiedemann, 1830
. Ausser. Zweifl. Ins. 2: 579. Type locality: China: Trentepohl.
Sepedon violacea Hendel, 1909
. Wien. Ent. Ztg. 28: 86. Type locality: China: Hong Kong.

Sepedon sauteri Hendel, 1911
. Ann. Mus. Natl. Hung. 9: 270. Type locality: China: Taiwan, Takao.
Sepedon sinensis Mayer, 1953
. Ann. Naturhist. Mus. Wien 59: 217. Type locality: China: Jiangsu, Nanjing.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–9.
Sepedon aenescens Wiedemann.
1. Male habitus, lateral view. 2. Frons, frontal view. 3. Head, lateral view. 4. Sternum 5. 5. Male postabdomen, lateral view. 6. Male postabdomen, caudal view. 7. Hypandrium, complete, ventral view. 8. Hypandrium (left part), lateral view. 9. Aedeagus and apodemes, lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution . China ( Heilongjiang , Liaoning , Hebei , Beijing ,
Tianjin
, Shanxi , Shaanxi ,
Inner Mongolia
, Ningxia , Xinjiang , Sichuan , Guizhou , Yunnan , Hubei , Hunan , Shanghai , Zhejiang , Fujian , Guangxi , Guangdong , Hainan , Hong Kong ,
Taiwan )
; Pakistan , India , Nepal , Thailand , Japan , Philippines , Bangladesh , Afghanistan , Far East of Russia , Korea ( Yano, 1968 ; Knutson & Orth, 1984 ).

Remarks.
Sepedon aenescens
is based on a male from China ( type locality: Trentepohl) ( Wiedemann, 1830 ). The lectotype was designated by Knutson in Knutson & Orth (1984) . The junior synonym
S. violacea
was described from a female recorded at Hong Kong ( Hendel, 1909 ), the junior synonym
S. sinensis
is based on a male from the vicinity of Nanking, China ( Mayer, 1953 ), and the junior synonym.
S. sauteri
was described from Taiwan ( Hendel, 1911 ).

This species is very similar to
S. sphegea
. Most published literature ( Rozkošný, 1987 ; Knutson & Orth, 1984 ) describes the primary external difference between them to be the color of the antennal scape (see the couplet 3 in the key) ( Fig. 3 , Fig. 62 ). However, this subtle difference is not particularly useful for identification because the scape color of
S. aenescens
varies from yellow to dark brown. Because of this,
S. aenescens
and
S. sphegea
often have been misidentified for each other (
Rozkošný et al ., 2010
).

To discover more reliable external identification characters between the two species, the first author checked 102 specimens labeled
S. sphegea
( 62 males and 40 females ) in MNHNP . The following differences seem to be reliable: 1) the body of
S. aenescens
is somewhat smaller and more slender than that of
S. sphegea
; 2) besides having a paler antennal scape than that of
S. sphegea
, the body of
S. aenescens
is paler (bluish black) than that of
S. sphegea
(darker blackish rather than blue); 3) the leg color differs between the two species, with the legs contrasting reddish in
S. sphegea
( Fig. 61 ) and yellow in
S. aenescens
( Fig. 1 ).

Despite all of these characters, the male terminalia of
S. aenescens
( Fig. 5–9 ) and
S. sphegea
( Fig. 63–67 ), including the cerci, surstylus, and hypandrium, show no distinctive differences. This result is inconsistent with that of Knutson & Freidberg (1983) and Knutson & Orth (1984) . In this paper we regard them in the traditional sense, as separate species, and will continue to do so until we can find new evidence such as molecular differences.
